revision.comment: /* Painting */copy edit with [[Wikipedia:AutoWikiBrowser/General_fixes|General fixes]]; [[Template:Citation_Style_documentation#url|url trimming]] of identifying info per[[WP:LINKSTOAVOID]]
revision.text:
The '''largest creative work''' is the largest or longest item in different fields of [[creative work]]s. Some pieces were created with the specific intention of holding the record while others have been recognised for their size after completion.
==Literature== [[Image:Yongle Dadian Encyclopedia 1403.jpg|thumb|A page from the largest general encyclopedia, the ''[[Yongle Encyclopedia]]''.]] *The largest known general [[encyclopedia]] is the ''[[Yongle Encyclopedia]]'' commissioned by the [[Yongle Emperor]] of China's [[Ming dynasty]] in 1403. It comprised 22,937 manuscript scrolls in 11,095 volumes, occupying {{convert|40|m3|abbr=off}}. *The longest poem in any language is the [[Mahabharata]], with more than 100,000 couplets.{{Citation needed|date=October 2008}} *The longest epic cycle is the Tibetan [[Epic of King Gesar]], which contains over 20 million words in more than one million verses.{{Citation needed|date=October 2008}}
==Performing arts==
===Film=== *''[[Logistics (film)|Logistics]]'', directed by Erika Magnusson and Daniel Andersson, is officially the world's longest film. Running 51,420 minutes (857 hours) in length, the film follows the production cycle of a [[pedometer]] in reverse chronological order.
===Music=== *The longest [[music]]al performance began on 1 January 2000 and is set to last for 1000 years before repeating. Composed by [[Jem Finer]], ''[[Longplayer]]'' is played in a 19th-century lighthouse near [[Canary Wharf]], London, and other public listening posts.<ref>[[The Guardian]]. 4 September 2009. "[https://www.theguardian.com/music/musicblog/2009/sep/04/jem-finer-longplayer]" How to play music that lasts 1,000 years. Accessed 25 March 2014.</ref>
===Television=== *The [[List of longest running U.S. television series|longest running U.S. television series]] is ''[[Meet the Press]]'', a news program which started on 6 November 1947 and continues today.
===Theatre=== ''[[The Mousetrap]]'' has been running continuously in [[West End of London|London]] since 1952. It has by far the longest initial run of any play in history, with more than 25,000 performances taking place,<ref name="telegraph18nov12">{{cite news | url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/theatre/drama/9686732/Agatha-Christies-The-Mousetrap-celebrates-its-60th-anniversary-with-star-studded-show.html | title=Agatha Christie's The Mousetrap celebrates its 60th anniversary with star-studded show | work=The Daily Telegraph | date=18 Nov 2012 | accessdate=November 19, 2012 | author=Marsden, Sam | location=London}}</ref> and the longest running show (of any type) of the modern era.
==Visual arts==
===Painting=== *The largest [[painting]] by a single-artist according to the international guinness book of world records was completed by Duka Siroglavic. It measured {{convert|10800|m2|abbr=on}} and was created by Ðuka Siroglavic of Croatia in [[Bol, Croatia|Bol]], between 15 February and 15 July 2007.<ref> http://www.guinnessworldrecords.com/world-records/70217-largest-painting</ref> Previous record holders included David Aberg's {{Convert|8000|m2|abbr=on|adj=on}} "Mother Earth," (2006) and an Eric Waugh's {{Convert|3850|m2|abbr=on|adj=on}}, "Hero" (2002).<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/id/14309591/ns/world_news-weird_news/t/art-world-really-big/|title=World’s largest painting confirmed - World news - Weird news|date=8 Nov 2016|work=[[NBCNews.com]]|accessdate=22 March 2017}}</ref>
===Sculpture=== *The largest [[glass]] sculpture is ''Fiori di Como'' by [[Dale Chihuly]], found on the ceiling of the lobby for [[Las Vegas Valley|Las Vegas's]] [[Bellagio (hotel and casino)|Bellagio]] hotel. It measures {{convert|2000|sqft|m2|order=flip|abbr=on}}.<ref>GlassonWeb. August 2005. "[http://www.glassonweb.com/articles/article/298/ Fiori di Como] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061018011841/http://www.glassonweb.com/articles/article/298/ |date=18 October 2006 }}". Accessed 2 September 2006.</ref>
===Textiles=== The world's largest hand woven carpet is a [[Persian carpet]] made in Iran and completed in 2007.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.nationalgeographic.com/news/2007/08/070801-iran-picture.html |title=Photo in the News: World's Largest Carpet Woven for Worshippers |publisher=News.nationalgeographic.com |date=28 October 2010 |accessdate=24 June 2013}}</ref> It has 2.2 billion knots, measuring {{convert|5625|m2|abbr=on}}.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.payvand.com/news/07/aug/1001.html |title=World's largest carpet unveiled in Iran |publisher=Payvand Iran News |date= 1 August 2007 |accessdate=24 June 2013}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Louvre]] – the world's [[list of largest art museums in the world|largest]] [[art gallery]] *[[List of largest buildings in the world]] *[[Unfinished work]]
==References== {{Reflist}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2011}}
[[Category:World records]] [[Category:Superlatives]]

[[Image:Florida hurricane (1900-1949) tracks.png|right|thumb|320px|Tracks of hurricanes over Florida from 1900 to 1949]] The '''list of Florida hurricanes from 1900 to 1949''' encompasses 108 [[Atlantic hurricane|Atlantic tropical cyclones]] that affected the [[U.S. state]] of [[Florida]]. Collectively, tropical cyclones in Florida during the time period resulted in about $4 billion (2008 USD) in damage. Additionally, tropical cyclones in Florida were directly responsible for about 3,550 fatalities during the time period, most of which from the [[1928 Okeechobee Hurricane]]. The [[1947 Atlantic hurricane season|1947 season]] was the year with the most tropical cyclones affecting the state, with a total of 6 systems. The [[1905 Atlantic hurricane season|1905]], [[1908 Atlantic hurricane season|1908]], [[1913 Atlantic hurricane season|1913]], [[1927 Atlantic hurricane season|1927]], [[1931 Atlantic hurricane season|1931]], [[1942 Atlantic hurricane season|1942]], and [[1943 Atlantic hurricane season|1943]] seasons were the only years during the time period in which a storm did not affect the Floridian coasts.
The strongest hurricane to hit the state during the time period was the [[Labor Day Hurricane of 1935]], which also bears the distinction of being the strongest recorded hurricane to strike the United States.<ref name="damage 2006">{{cite web|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/pdf/NWS-TPC-5.pdf|title=THE DEADLIEST, COSTLIEST, AND MOST INTENSE UNITED STATES TROPICAL CYCLONES FROM 1851 TO 2006 (AND OTHER FREQUENTLY REQUESTED HURRICANE FACTS) |author1=Eric S. Blake |author2=Edward N. Rappaport |author3=Christopher W. Landsea |date=April 2007|accessdate=2007-04-11|pages=26|format=PDF}}</ref> Several other major hurricanes struck the state during the time period, including the [[1926 Miami Hurricane]], the 1928 Okeechobee Hurricane, and a cyclone each in 1945 and 1949. All of these storms made [[landfall (meteorology)|landfall]] as [[Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Scale|Category 4]] hurricanes.
{{clear-right}} {{horizontal TOC|align=center|nonum=yes|limit=2}} ==1900–1909== [[Image:1906 Pensacola Hurricane Damage.PNG|right|thumb|250px|Shipping damage in [[Pensacola, Florida|Pensacola]] from 1906 hurricane]] * September 5, 1900 – The [[Galveston Hurricane of 1900|Great Galveston Hurricane]] passes over or just to the west of the western [[Florida Keys]] as a tropical storm, producing tropical storm force winds throughout the state. Prior warning keeps nearly all ships in the state at port, and no damage is reported.<ref name="1900mwr">{{cite web|author=United States Weather Bureau|year=1900|title=Monthly Weather Review|accessdate=2007-01-25|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/hrd/hurdat/mwr_pdf/1900.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> * October 12, 1900 – A tropical storm hits near [[Cedar Key, Florida|Cedar Key]], crosses the state, and exits near [[Jacksonville, Florida|Jacksonville]].{{Easy Hurdat}} * June 13, 1901 – The first storm of the season hits just east of [[Apalachicola, Florida|Apalachicola]].<ref name="hurdat">{{cite web|author=Hurricane Research Division|year=2007|title=Atlantic hurricane best track|publisher=[[NOAA]]|accessdate=2007-09-23|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/hrd/hurdat/easyhurdat_5106.html}}</ref> * August 10, 1901 – A tropical storm moves ashore near [[Fort Lauderdale, Florida|Fort Lauderdale]].<ref name="1901mwr">{{cite web|author=United States Weather Bureau|year=1901|title=Monthly Weather Review|accessdate=2007-01-25|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/hrd/hurdat/mwr_pdf/1901.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> * September 17, 1901 – [[Pensacola, Florida|Pensacola]] is struck by a tropical storm which produces heavy rainfall along its path.<ref name="1901mwr"/> * September 28, 1901 – A tropical storm makes landfall near Apalachicola, though its effects, if any, are unknown.<ref name="hurdat"/> * June 14, 1902 – The first storm of the season hits near [[Tallahassee, Florida|Tallahassee]], with no severe impact reported.<ref name="1902mwr">{{cite web|author=E.B. Garriott|year=1902|title=1902 Monthly Weather Review|publisher=U.S. Weather Bureau|accessdate=2007-09-23|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/hrd/hurdat/mwr_pdf/1902.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> * October 10, 1902 – Pensacola is struck by a tropical storm; its impact is unknown.<ref name="1902mwr"/> * September 11, 1903 – A hurricane moves ashore near Fort Lauderdale, and after emerging into the [[Gulf of Mexico]] it hits near [[Panama City, Florida|Panama City]]. Moderate damage to structures and crops is reported across the state, with monetary damage totaling about $650,000 (1903 USD, $15.5 million 2008 USD), and nine lives are lost when a British schooner capsizes near [[Delray Beach, Florida|Delray Beach]].<ref name="1903mwr">{{cite web|author=E.B. Garriott|year=1903|title=1903 Monthly Weather Review|publisher=U.S. Weather Bureau|accessdate=2007-09-23|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/hrd/hurdat/mwr_pdf/1903.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> * October 17, 1904 – Light structural damage and locally heavy crop losses result from a hurricane hitting south of [[Miami, Florida|Miami]] before executing a counter-clockwise loop and striking again near [[Chokoloskee, Florida|Chokoloskee]]. Offshore, seven lives are lost after a schooner founders.<ref name="1904mwr">{{cite web|author=Alfred Henry|year=1904|title=1904 Monthly Weather Review|publisher=U.S. Weather Bureau|accessdate=2007-09-25|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/hrd/hurdat/mwr_pdf/1904.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> * November 3, 1904 – The fifth storm of the season made landfall as a tropical storm near Pensacola.<ref name="hurdat"/> * June 12, 1906 – A tropical storm moves ashore near Panama City; no severe impact is reported.<ref name="hurdat"/> * June 17, 1906 – A hurricane produces locally strong winds as it crosses the extreme southeastern portion of the state.<ref name="metahur"/> * September 27, 1906 – Southern [[Mississippi]] is [[1906 Mississippi hurricane|struck by a moderate hurricane]], with strong winds and waves affecting much of the Florida west coast. It is considered among the worst cyclones on record at Pensacola, where high tides cause severe shipping damage. The hurricane results in 32 casualties and $3.4 million in damage (1906 USD, $81 million 2008 USD).<ref name="1906mwr">{{cite web|author=E.B. Garriott|year=1906|title=1906 Monthly Weather Review|accessdate=2007-10-01|publisher=U.S. Weather Bureau|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/hrd/hurdat/mwr_pdf/1906.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> [[Image:Florida East Coast Railway's Overseas Extension 1906.jpg|right|thumb|250px|Hundreds of workers on the [[Florida East Coast Railway]] were lost when a hurricane moves through the region]] * October 18, 1906 – The [[1906 Florida Keys hurricane]] moves through the Florida Keys before crossing the extreme southeastern portion of the state. High seas destroy hundreds of vessels in the region, including many houseboats of the hundreds of workers on the Florida East Coast Railway construction through the Keys; a total of 135 workers are killed. On the mainland, the cyclone results in severe crop damage and the destruction of many houses in the Miami area, and across the state the hurricane causes 141 fatalities and over $360,000 in damage (1906 USD, $8.6 million 2008 USD).<ref name="1906mwr"/> The storm tracked northward and ultimately made a second landfall as a tropical storm near Jacksonville.<ref name="hurdat"/> * June 28, 1907 – The first storm of the season moves ashore near Panama City, with no severe impact reported.<ref name="hurdat"/> * September 18, 1907 – A tropical depression crosses the southern portion of the state; no damage or fatalities are reported.<ref name="hurdat"/> * September 28, 1907 – Strong winds and heavy rainfall occurs in association with a tropical storm striking the [[Florida Panhandle]].<ref name="1907mwr">{{cite web|author=E.B. Garriott|year=1907|title=September 1907 Forecasts and Warnings|publisher=U.S. Weather Bureau|accessdate=2007-10-01|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/hrd/hurdat/mwr_pdf/1907.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> * June 28, 1909 – Fort Lauderdale is struck by a tropical storm, which produces light winds and otherwise little impact.<ref name="hurdat"/> * August 29, 1909 – A weak tropical storm crosses the eastern portion of the state, resulting in minor impact.<ref name="1909mwr">{{cite web|author=E.B. Garriott|year=1909|title=1909 Monthly Weather Review|publisher=U.S. Weather Bureau|accessdate=2007-10-01|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/hrd/hurdat/mwr_pdf/1909.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> * September 20, 1909 – The western Florida Panhandle receives minor damage, mostly to shipping, from a hurricane hitting southern [[Louisiana]].<ref name="1909mwr"/> * September 25, 1909 – A tropical depression crosses the southern portion of the state, with no severe impact reported.<ref name="1909mwr"/> * October 11, 1909 – The Florida Keys are brushed by a major hurricane, which destroys about 400 buildings and 300 boats; damage is estimated at $1 million (1909 USD, $24 million 2008 USD). Thirteen fatalities are reported throughout the state.<ref name="1909mwr"/>
==1910–1919== * October 17, 1910 – The Florida Keys are brushed by [[1910 Cuba hurricane|a major hurricane]], which strikes the mainland near [[Fort Myers, Florida|Fort Myers]] as a strong [[Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Scale|Category 2]] hurricane a day later. High tides and heavy rainfall causes flooding in the keys, though damage is fairly minor. On the mainland, the hurricane destroys 10% of the state's citrus crop, and causes moderate damage elsewhere. Across the state, the hurricane results in around $360,000 (1910 USD, $8.3 million 2008 USD) and eleven fatalities.<ref name="1910mwr">{{cite web|author=Edward B. Howie|year=1910|title=1910 Monthly Weather Review|publisher=U.S. Weather Bureau|accessdate=2007-09-28|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/hrd/hurdat/mwr_pdf/1910.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> * August 4, 1911 – A tropical depression develops near the [[Alabama]]/Florida border, and produces light rainfall and winds across the northern portion of the state.<ref>{{cite web|author=Hurricane Research Division|year=2006|title=Raw observations for Tropical Storm #1 of 1911|publisher=NOAA|accessdate=2007-09-28|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/hrd/hurdat/excelfiles_centerfix/191101.xls|format=XLS}}</ref> * August 11, 1911 – Pensacola experiences 80 mph (130 km/h) winds and 4.48 inches (114 mm) of precipitation in association with a hurricane hitting southern Alabama; damage is fairly minor.<ref name="1911mwr">{{cite web|author=W.F. Reed|year=1911|title=1911 Monthly Weather Review|accessdate=2007-09-28|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/hrd/hurdat/mwr_pdf/1911.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> * August 28, 1911 – A hurricane makes landfall on extreme southern [[South Carolina]], with its large circulation producing moderate precipitation in northeastern Florida.<ref>{{cite web|author=Hurricane Research Division|year=2006|title=Raw observations for Hurricane #3 of 1911|publisher=NOAA|accessdate=2007-09-28|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/hrd/hurdat/excelfiles_centerfix/191103.xls|format=XLS}}</ref> * November 1, 1911 – Shortly after becoming an [[extratropical cyclone]], a tropical storm hits near Cedar Key and causes unsettled conditions across the state for several days.<ref name="1911mwr"/> * June 13, 1912 – The first storm of the season hits southern Louisiana, which produces about 3 inches (75 mm) of rainfall in Pensacola.<ref>{{cite web|author=Hurricane Research Division|year=2006|title=Raw observations for Tropical Storm #1 of 1912|publisher=NOAA|accessdate=2007-09-26|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/hrd/hurdat/excelfiles_centerfix/191201.xls|format=XLS}}</ref> * September 10, 1912 – A tropical depression forms in the Gulf of Mexico and later moves ashore in extreme southeastern Mississippi; the developing disturbance produces heavy rainfall, including 23.2 inches (588 mm) at Cedar Key, and while making landfall it causes minor shipping and coastal damage in Pensacola.<ref name="metahur"/> * September 17, 1914 – The only tropical storm of the season strikes near the [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]]/Florida border, producing moderate rainfall and above normal tides.<ref name="metahur">{{cite web|author=Chris Landsea |year=2008 |title=Documentation of Atlantic Tropical Cyclones Changes in HURDAT |publisher=Hurricane Research Division |accessdate=2008-02-23 |url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/hrd/hurdat/metadata_master.html |display-authors=etal |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110604063810/http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/hrd/hurdat/metadata_master.html |archivedate=2011-06-04 |df= }}</ref> * August 1, 1915 – A minimal hurricane hits near [[Daytona Beach, Florida|Daytona Beach]], dropping moderate precipitation and causing some damage.<ref name="metahur"/> * September 4, 1915 – Apalachicola is struck by a hurricane that causes above normal tides and locally moderate damage.<ref name="1915mwr">{{cite web|author=Edward H. Bowie|year=1915|title=1915 Monthly Weather Review|publisher=U.S. Weather Bureau|accessdate=2007-09-30|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/hrd/hurdat/mwr_pdf/1915.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> * September 29, 1915 – A [[New Orleans Hurricane of 1915|hurricane]] produces above normal tides in Pensacola.<ref name="metahur"/> * May 14, 1916 – A minimal tropical storm crosses the state.<ref name="metahur"/> * July 5, 1916 – High tides and about $1 million (1916 USD, $20 million 2008 USD) in the Pensacola area are caused by a [[1916 Gulf Coast hurricane|hurricane]] making landfall on southern Mississippi.<ref name="1916mwr">{{cite web|author=H.C. Frankenfield|year=1916|title=1916 Monthly Weather Review|publisher=U.S. Weather Bureau|accessdate=2007-09-30|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/hrd/hurdat/mwr_pdf/1916.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> * August 24, 1916 – A tropical storm moves across the southeastern portion of the state.<ref name="metahur"/> * September 13, 1916 – A [[low pressure area]] moves ashore near [[Cape Canaveral]], with the worst of its effects remaining offshore.<ref name="1916mwr"/> Originally, it was classified as a tropical storm.<ref name="metahur" /> * October 18, 1916 – Pensacola is struck by a strong Category 2 hurricane, recording peak wind gusts of around 120 mph (195 km/h). Despite the intensity, overall damage is small due to its fast track.<ref name="1916mwr"/> The hurricane causes one drowning in Pensacola.<ref>{{cite news|author=Associated Press|date=1916-10-19|title=General Damage Small|accessdate=2007-09-30|url=http://www.thehurricanearchive.com/Viewer.aspx?img=10005194_clean&firstvisit=true&src=search&currentResult=0&currentPage=0|format=PDF|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160118121151/http://www.thehurricanearchive.com/Viewer.aspx?img=10005194_clean&firstvisit=true&src=search&currentResult=0&currentPage=0|archivedate=2016-01-18|df=}}</ref> * November 15, 1916 – The remnants of a tropical storm brush the Florida Keys, but fails to produce significant damage in the state.<ref name="1916mwr"/> * September 29, 1917 – A major hurricane moves makes landfall near Pensacola with recorded sustained winds of 103 mph (166 km/h) and gusts to 125 mph (202 km/h); the passage of the cyclone results in 5 fatalities and about $170,000 in damage (1917 USD, $2.9 million 2008 USD).<ref>{{cite web|author=H.C. Frankenfield|year=1917|title=1917 Monthly Weather Review|publisher=U.S. Weather Bureau|accessdate=2007-10-01|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/hrd/hurdat/mwr_pdf/1917.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> * June 22, 1918 – A tropical depression crosses the southern portion of the state.<ref name="metahur"/> * July 4, 1919 – The first storm of the season hits just west of Pensacola, with no severe impact reported.<ref name="hurdat"/> * September 9, 1919 – The [[1919 Florida Keys Hurricane]] passes about 50 miles (80 km) south of [[Key West, Florida|Key West]], producing strong winds and heavy rainfall reaching an estimated peak of 13.4 inches (340 mm). Shipping losses are heavy, and damage in the Florida Keys is estimated at $2 million (1919 USD, $25 million 2008 USD).<ref name="1919mwr">{{cite web|author=H.C. Frankenfield|year=1919|title=Weather Warnings for September 1919|publisher=U.S. Weather Bureau|accessdate=2007-10-01|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/hrd/hurdat/mwr_pdf/1919.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> * September 30, 1919 – Moving ashore along the Georgia coastline, a tropical storm brushes northeastern Florida.<ref name="metahur"/>
==1920–1929== [[Image:Miami beach2.jpg|right|thumb|250px|Damage in Miami from 1926 Miami Hurricane]] * September 22, 1920 – A hurricane strikes southern Louisiana, with its outer rainbands producing trace precipitation and gale force winds in the western Florida Panhandle.<ref name="1920mwr">{{cite web|author1=Isaac Cline |author2=Alexander Mitchell |lastauthoramp=yes|year=1920|title=1920 Monthly Weather Review|publisher=U.S. Weather Bureau|accessdate=2007-09-26|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/hrd/hurdat/mwr_pdf/1920.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> * September 30, 1920 – The final storm of season makes landfall near Cedar Key, bringing rainfall and gusty winds along much of the western coast. It causes coastal flooding and crop damage, and in [[St. Petersburg, Florida|St. Petersburg]] the storm results in an indirect fatality.<ref name="1920mwr"/> * October 25, 1921 – The [[Tampa Bay Hurricane of 1921]] strikes near [[Clearwater, Florida|Clearwater]], producing moderate winds, a storm tide reaching 10.5 feet (3.2 m), and heavy rainfall peaking at 11.73 inches (298 mm) at [[St. Leo, Florida|St. Leo]]. About five people are killed as a result of the storm, and damage is estimated at $5 million (1921 USD, $60 million 2008 USD).<ref>{{cite web|author=Edward H. Bowie|year=1921|title=The Hurricane of October 25, 1921 at Tampa, Florida|publisher=U.S. Weather Bureau|accessdate=2007-09-26|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/hrd/hurdat/mwr_pdf/1921.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> * October 17, 1922 – A weak tropical storm moves ashore just west of the Florida/Alabama; there were no reports of serious damage.<ref name="hurdat"/> * October 16, 1923 – Winds reach 64 mph (103 km/h) at Pensacola in association with a hurricane hitting Louisiana, which causes shipping damage in northwestern Florida.<ref name="1923mwr">{{cite web|author=W.P. Day|year=1924|title=Tropical Disturbances During the Hurricane Season of 1923|publisher=U.S. Weather Bureau|accessdate=2007-09-25|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/hrd/hurdat/mwr_pdf/1923.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> * October 17, 1923 – A tropical storm makes landfall on southern Mississippi, with winds reaching 56 mph (90 km/h) in Pensacola.<ref name="1923mwr"/> * September 15, 1924 – A minimal hurricane moves ashore near Panama City, producing winds of up to 80 mph (130 km/h) but little damage.<ref name="1924mwr">{{cite web|author=W.P. Day|year=1924|title=Tropical Disturbances During the Hurricane Season of 1924|publisher=U.S. Weather Bureau|accessdate=2007-09-25|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/hrd/hurdat/mwr_pdf/1924.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> * October 21, 1924 – Moderate crop and flooding damage occurs after a hurricane strikes the southwestern portion of the state.<ref name="oct24">{{cite web|author=U.S. Weather Bureau|year=1924|title=Severe Hail and Local Wind Storms, October 1924|accessdate=2007-09-25|url=http://docs.lib.noaa.gov/rescue/mwr/052/mwr-052-10-0511a.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> * December 1, 1925 – Moving ashore south of [[Tampa, Florida|Tampa]] later than any other United States tropical cyclone on record, a [[1925 Florida tropical storm|tropical storm]] crosses the central portion of the state, dropping 14.1 inches (357 mm) of rain at Miami and heavily eroding northeastern beaches; damage is estimated at $3 million (1925 USD, $40.8 million 2016 USD). The storm kills 16 people in the state.<ref>{{cite web|author=U.S. Weather Bureau|year=1925|title=Storms and Weather Warnings of 1925|accessdate=2007-09-23|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/general/lib/lib1/nhclib/mwreviews/1925.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> * July 27, 1926 – A moderate [[Nassau Hurricane of 1926|hurricane]] moves ashore near [[Cocoa Beach, Florida|Cocoa Beach]], killing one person and causing about $3 million in damage (1926 USD, $36.5 million 2008 USD), primarily from fruit losses.<ref>{{cite web|author=U.S. Weather Bureau|year=1926|title=Severe Local Hail and Wind Storms, July 1926|accessdate=2007-09-23|url=http://docs.lib.noaa.gov/rescue/mwr/054/mwr-054-07-0310.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> * September 17, 1926 – The Florida Keys are brushed by a slow-moving and weak [[1926 Atlantic hurricane season#Tropical Storm Seven|tropical storm]].<ref name="1926mwr">{{cite web|author=Charles Mitchell|year=1926|title=1926 Monthly Weather Review|publisher=U.S. Weather Bureau|accessdate=2007-09-23|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/general/lib/lib1/nhclib/mwreviews/1926.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> * September 18, 1926 – The [[1926 Miami Hurricane]] makes landfall as a Category 4 hurricane near Miami. A powerful storm surge in excess of 11 feet (3.3 m) floods [[Miami Beach, Florida|Miami Beach]], while strong winds recorded at up to 128 mph (209 km/h) cause severe damage across the region. About 4,725 houses are destroyed with another 9,100 damaged, leaving about 25,000 people homeless, and damage in the Miami area is estimated at $76 million (1926 USD, $926 million 2008 USD).<ref name="1926mwr"/> Due to uncertainties, such as the inclusion of non-white fatalities, the [[National Weather Service]] reports the death toll in the state at 372 casualties, with a note that the total could be several dozen greater.<ref>{{cite web|author=Russell F. Pfost|year=2003|title=Reassessing the Impact of Two Historical Florida Hurricanes|publisher=American Meteorological Society|accessdate=2007-10-02|url=http://ams.allenpress.com/archive/1520-0477/84/10/pdf/i1520-0477-84-10-1367.pdf|format=PDF|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=http://archive.wikiwix.com/cache/20071004154121/http://ams.allenpress.com/archive/1520-0477/84/10/pdf/i1520-0477-84-10-1367.pdf|archivedate=2007-10-04|df=}} </ref> Damage is heavy in Pensacola from the final landfall of the hurricane.<ref name="1926mwr"/> * October 21, 1926 – Passing a short distance east of the Florida Keys, a [[1926 Atlantic hurricane season#Hurricane Ten|hurricane]] causes light damage and power outages near the coastline; one person is killed after being struck by flying debris.<ref>{{cite news|author=Associated Press|date=1926-10-21|title=Miami and South Coast Cities Escape Furious West Indian Hurricane|accessdate=2007-09-23|url=http://www.thehurricanearchive.com/Viewer.aspx?img=49245332_clean&firstvisit=true&src=search&currentResult=0&currentPage=0|format=PDF|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160118121151/http://www.thehurricanearchive.com/Viewer.aspx?img=49245332_clean&firstvisit=true&src=search&currentResult=0&currentPage=0|archivedate=2016-01-18|df=}}</ref> [[Image:1928 Okeechobee Aftermath 14.jpg|thumb|right|300px|Destruction in Delray Beach from 1928 Okeechobee Hurricane]] * August 7, 1928 – The [[1928 Atlantic hurricane season#Hurricane One|first hurricane]] of the season moves ashore near [[Fort Pierce, Florida|Fort Pierce]], causing moderate damage to highways, crops, and telephone lines;<ref name="aug28">{{cite web|author=R. Weightman|year=1928|title=West Indian Hurricanes of August 1928|publisher=U.S. Weather Bureau|accessdate=2007-08-08|url=http://docs.lib.noaa.gov/rescue/mwr/056/mwr-056-10-0411.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> damage is estimated at $5 million (1928 USD, $63 million 2008 USD),<ref>{{cite web|author=Associated Press|date=1928-08-08|title=Tropical Gale Lashes Florida Coast|accessdate=2007-08-08|url=http://www.thehurricanearchive.com/Viewer.aspx?img=60778207_clean&firstvisit=true&src=search&currentResult=1&currentPage=0|format=PDF|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160118121151/http://www.thehurricanearchive.com/Viewer.aspx?img=60778207_clean&firstvisit=true&src=search&currentResult=1&currentPage=0|archivedate=2016-01-18|df=}}</ref> and there were four reported casualties near [[Jupiter, Florida|Jupiter]].<ref>{{cite web|author=United Press International|date=1928-08-10|title=Hurricane Swept Area of Florida Now Threatened By Floods|accessdate=2007-08-08|url=http://www.thehurricanearchive.com/Viewer.aspx?img=24196104_clean&firstvisit=true&src=search&currentResult=5&currentPage=0|format=PDF|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160118121151/http://www.thehurricanearchive.com/Viewer.aspx?img=24196104_clean&firstvisit=true&src=search&currentResult=5&currentPage=0|archivedate=2016-01-18|df=}}</ref> * August 14, 1928 – A [[1928 Atlantic hurricane season#Hurricane Two|tropical storm]] strikes near Apalachicola after crossing the Florida Keys, causing minor damage.<ref name="aug28"/> * September 17, 1928 – The [[1928 Okeechobee Hurricane]] makes landfall between Jupiter and [[Boca Raton, Florida|Boca Raton]] as the equivalent of a Category 4 hurricane, producing a storm surge of 10 feet and waves of up to 20 feet which causes severe damage near the coast. As it crosses the state, strongly northerly winds pile up water from [[Lake Okeechobee]] at its southern end, which surpasses the levee and floods a 450 mi<sup>2</sup> (1165 km<sup>2</sup>) area up to 12 feet (3.6 m) deep. The flooding, which lasts for several weeks, causes severe loss of human and animal life; damage in the state is estimated at $25 million (1928 USD, $315 million 2008 USD). The death toll is unknown, but is estimated at over 2,500 fatalities, making the cyclone the second deadliest hurricane in the United States. * September 28, 1929 – A [[1929 Florida Hurricane|major hurricane]] crosses the southern portion of the state, and two days later hits near Apalachicola.<ref name="costliest">{{cite web|author1=Eric S. Blake |author2=Edward N. Rappaport |author3=Christopher W. Landsea |last-author-amp=yes |year=2007|title=The Deadliest, Costliest, and Most Intense United States Tropical Cyclones from 1851 to 2006 (other frequently requested hurricane facts)|publisher=National Weather Service|accessdate=2007-08-08|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/pdf/NWS-TPC-5.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> The cyclone produces several tornadoes in the Miami area, and despite its ferocity overall damage is minor; three people are killed in association with the storm.<ref>{{cite web|author=Charles Mitchell|year=1929|title=The Tropical Cyclone of September 18 – October 4|publisher=U.S. Weather Bureau|accessdate=2007-08-08|url=http://docs.lib.noaa.gov/rescue/mwr/057/mwr-057-10-0418.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref>
==1930–1939== * August 9, 1930 – The [[1930 Dominican Republic hurricane|second tropical storm]] of the season crosses through the center of the state; as it previously crossed the mountainous terrain of the [[Greater Antilles]], the storm is severely weakened, and causes no reported serious damage in the state.<ref name="1930apps">{{cite web|author=Various|year=1930|title=Appendices to the Santo Domingo Hurricane of September 1 to 5, 1930|publisher=Weather Bureau Office|accessdate=2007-06-14|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/general/lib/lib1/nhclib/mwreviews/1930.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> * August 30, 1932 – A [[1932 Atlantic hurricane season#Hurricane Three|tropical storm]] crosses the southern portion of the state, causing some minor structural damage and minor power outages.<ref name="ap83132">{{cite web|author=Associated Press|year=1932|title=Hurricane Danger Passes from Florida|accessdate=2007-06-14|url=http://www.thehurricanearchive.com/Viewer.aspx?img=10540997_clean&firstvisit=true&src=search&currentResult=0&currentPage=0|format=PDF|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160118121151/http://www.thehurricanearchive.com/Viewer.aspx?img=10540997_clean&firstvisit=true&src=search&currentResult=0&currentPage=0|archivedate=2016-01-18|df=}}</ref> * September 15, 1932 – A [[1932 Atlantic hurricane season#Tropical Storm Five|weak tropical storm]] produces light winds but no reported damage after hitting near [[Steinhatchee, Florida|Steinhatchee]].<ref name="1932mwr">{{cite web|author=W.J. Humphreys|year=1932|title=1932 Monthly Weather Review|publisher=U.S. Weather Bureau|accessdate=2007-06-14|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/general/lib/lib1/nhclib/mwreviews/1932.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> * July 30, 1933 – Moving ashore near Fort Pierce, [[1933 Atlantic hurricane season#Hurricane Five|a minimal hurricane]] causes minor damage to crops, roofs, and signs.<ref name="july311933">{{cite web|author=Times Herald|date=1933-07-31|title=Florida Effects from Hurricane|accessdate=2007-06-14|url=http://www.thehurricanearchive.com/FullViewer.aspx?img=wUP6BEk4rpmKID/6NLMW2viI7tHH0PFz1HYPxaUY79DTs29yjzQKTQ==|format=PDF|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927230701/http://www.thehurricanearchive.com/FullViewer.aspx?img=wUP6BEk4rpmKID%2F6NLMW2viI7tHH0PFz1HYPxaUY79DTs29yjzQKTQ%3D%3D|archivedate=2007-09-27|df=}}</ref> * August 20, 1933 – The [[1933 Atlantic hurricane season#Tropical Storm Six|sixth tropical storm]] of the season hits near Tallahassee, resulting in minor damage.<ref name="1933mwr">{{cite web|author=Charles L. Mitchell|year=1933|title=1933 Monthly Weather Review|publisher=U.S. Weather Bureau|accessdate=2007-06-14|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/general/lib/lib1/nhclib/mwreviews/1933.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> * September 1, 1933 – Passing to the south of Key West, a [[1933 Atlantic hurricane season#Hurricane Eleven|moderate hurricane]] produces light winds and minor damage in the Florida Keys.<ref name="1933mwr"/> * September 4, 1933 – A [[1933 Treasure Coast hurricane|Category 4 hurricane]] strikes Jupiter, with its strong winds destroying 4 million boxes of citrus fruit.<ref name="1933mwr"/> The passage of the hurricane results in $2 million in damage (1933 USD, $33 million 2008 USD) and two deaths.<ref>{{cite web|author=Williams & Duedall|year=1997|title=Tropical storms and Hurricanes in Florida|accessdate=2007-06-14|url=http://nsgl.gso.uri.edu/flsgp/flsgpb97001.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> * October 5, 1933 – Paralleling the Florida Keys before accelerating northeastward, a [[1933 Atlantic hurricane season#Hurricane Eighteen|major hurricane]] drops heavy rainfall and spawns a tornado in Miami, resulting in minor damage and two injuries.<ref name="oct51933">{{cite web|author=AP|date=1933-10-05|title=Tropical Storm Moves Northeast into the Ocean|accessdate=2007-06-14|url=http://www.thehurricanearchive.com/Viewer.aspx?img=8258004&firstvisit=true&currentResult=2&currentPage=0|format=PDF|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160118121151/http://www.thehurricanearchive.com/Viewer.aspx?img=8258004&firstvisit=true&currentResult=2&currentPage=0|archivedate=2016-01-18|df=}}</ref><ref name="oct41933">{{cite web|author=United Press International|date=1933-10-04|title=Hurricane Aims for Florida, Cuba|accessdate=2007-06-14|url=http://www.thehurricanearchive.com/Viewer.aspx?img=44969370&firstvisit=true&currentResult=0&currentPage=0|format=PDF|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160118121151/http://www.thehurricanearchive.com/Viewer.aspx?img=44969370&firstvisit=true&currentResult=0&currentPage=0|archivedate=2016-01-18|df=}}</ref> * May 27, 1934 – A [[1934 Atlantic hurricane season#Tropical Storm One|tropical storm]] crosses the southern portion of the state, though its impact is unknown.<ref name="1934mwr">{{cite web|author=Gordon Dunn|year=1934|title=Tropical Storms of 1934|publisher=U.S. Weather Bureau|accessdate=2007-05-27|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/general/lib/lib1/nhclib/mwreviews/1934.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> * July 22, 1934 – Moving southwestward into the northeastern portion of the state, a [[1934 Atlantic hurricane season#Hurricane Three|tropical storm]] produces gusty winds across the northern portion of the state.<ref name="1934mwr"/> * October 6, 1934 – The [[1934 Atlantic hurricane season#Tropical Storm Nine|ninth tropical storm]] of the season hits near Pensacola, and causes no marked damage along its path.<ref name="1934mwr"/> [[Image:Train derailed by the 1935 hurricane.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Relief train derailed by storm surge during the Labor Day Hurricane of 1935 near [[Islamorada, Florida|Islamorada]]]] * September 3, 1935 – The [[Labor Day Hurricane of 1935]] strikes [[Craig Key]] with sustained winds estimated at 185 mph (295 km/h) and gusts exceeding 200 mph (320 km/h), one of only three hurricanes to hit the United States at [[List of Category 5 Atlantic hurricanes|Category 5]] status on the [[Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Scale|Saffir-Simpson Scale]]. A pressure of 892 [[Bar (unit)|mbar]] (26.35 inHg) is recorded at landfall, which at the time is the lowest reported pressure in the [[Western Hemisphere]]. A small but violent cyclone, the hurricane results in almost complete destruction over a distance of about 30 miles (48 km), much of it caused from its powerful [[storm surge]]. One estimate by the [[International Red Cross and Red Crescent Movement|Red Cross]] indicates 409 fatalities in the [[Florida Keys]], many of whom at war veteran work relief camps. It later hits near [[Cedar Key, Florida|Cedar Key]] as a major hurricane, where it causes further damage and flooding.<ref name="reanal">{{cite web|author=David A. Glenn|year=2005|title=A Reanalysis of the 1916, 1918, 1927, 1928, and 1935 Tropical Cyclones of the North Atlantic Basin|publisher=NOAA|accessdate=2007-05-09|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/hrd/hurdat/GlennThesis.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref><ref name="1935mwr">{{cite web|author=W.F. McDonald|year=1935|title=Hurricanes and Tropical Disturbances of 1935|publisher=U.S. Weather Bureau|accessdate=2007-05-09|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/general/lib/lib1/nhclib/mwreviews/1935.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> * September 28, 1935 – Passing a short distance of Miami, a [[1935 Atlantic hurricane season#Hurricane Four|major hurricane]] produces moderate winds, but there is little damage along the coast.<ref name="1935mwr"/><ref name="ap928">{{cite web|author=Associated Press|accessdate=2007-05-09|url=http://www.thehurricanearchive.com/Viewer.aspx?img=51425402&firstvisit=true&src=search&currentResult=0&currentPage=0|date=1935-09-28|title=Florida Escapes as Hurricane Veers Off|format=PDF|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160118121151/http://www.thehurricanearchive.com/Viewer.aspx?img=51425402&firstvisit=true&src=search&currentResult=0&currentPage=0|archivedate=2016-01-18|df=}}</ref> * November 4, 1935 – A cyclone known as the ''[[1935 Yankee hurricane|Yankee Hurricane]]'' moves ashore near Miami after developing near [[Bermuda]], and produces winds of up to 94 mph (152 km/h). The late-season storm results in a monetary damage total of $5.5 million (1935 USD, $87 million 2008 USD) across the southern portion of the state, much of it from roof damage. 5 deaths are reported in the state, with an additional 115 injuries.<ref name="1935mwr"/> * June 15, 1936 – The [[1936 Atlantic hurricane season#Tropical Storm One|first storm]] of the season hits about 20 miles (32 km) south of Fort Myers, and while crossing the state drops up to 15 inches (380 mm) of precipitation. The passage of the storm results in some flooding damage, as well as three indirect deaths from a plane crash.<ref name="mwr">{{Cite web|author=Ivan Ray Tannehill |year=1936 |title=Tropical Disturbances of 1936 |publisher=Weather Bureau |accessdate=2007-05-08 |url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/general/lib/lib1/nhclib/mwreviews/1936.pdf |format=PDF |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110104021938/http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/general/lib/lib1/nhclib/mwreviews/1936.pdf |archivedate=2011-01-04 |df= }}</ref> * July 29, 1936 – After moving across the southern portion of the state, a [[1936 Atlantic hurricane season#Hurricane Five|minimal hurricane]] moves ashore near Pensacola, causing fairly minor damage, largely limited to its second landfall. Four fatalities are indirectly related to the hurricane when a boat capsized in the Gulf of Mexico.<ref name="mwr"/> * August 21, 1936 – A weak [[1936 Atlantic hurricane season#Tropical Storm Nine|tropical storm]] makes landfall near Daytona Beach; it produces heavy rainfall but results in minimal damage.<ref name="mwr"/> * July 30, 1937 – The [[1937 Atlantic hurricane season#Tropical Storm One|first storm]] of the season hits near Clearwater, dropping moderate precipitation which reaches 8.88 inches (225 mm) near its landfall location; minor damage is reported.<ref name="jul37">{{cite web|author=Willis E. Hurd|year=1937|title=Small Tropical Disturbance of Late July, 1937|publisher=U.S. Weather Bureau|accessdate=2007-05-07|url=http://docs.lib.noaa.gov/rescue/mwr/065/mwr-065-07-0281b.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> * August 30, 1937 – Cape Canaveral is struck by a [[1937 Atlantic hurricane season|tropical storm]], and across the state it causes considerable minor damage. On the Florida Panhandle, its accompanying rainfall destroys several bridges.<ref name="aug37">{{cite web|author=Willis E. Hurd|year=1937|title=Tropical Disturbances on the North Atlantic Ocean, August 1937|publisher=U.S. Weather Bureau|accessdate=2007-05-07|url=http://docs.lib.noaa.gov/rescue/mwr/065/mwr-065-08-0303.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> * September 21, 1937 – A weak tropical storm hits near the mouth of the [[Steinhatchee River]], which results in minor damage and a few injuries from its accompanying heavy rainfall.<ref name="sept37">{{cite web|author=Willis E. Hurd|year=1937|title=Tropical Disturbances on the North Atlantic Ocean, September 1937|publisher=U.S. Weather Bureau|accessdate=2007-05-07|url=http://docs.lib.noaa.gov/rescue/mwr/065/mwr-065-09-0332.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> * September 17, 1938 – The [[New England Hurricane of 1938]] was initially forecast to strike Florida, with storm warnings issued from Jacksonville through Key West.<ref name="1938gh">{{cite web|author=I.R. Tannehill|year=1938|title=Hurricane of September 16–22, 1938|publisher=U.S. Weather Bureau|accessdate=2007-05-07|url=http://docs.lib.noaa.gov/rescue/mwr/066/mwr-066-09-0286.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> * October 24, 1938 – Shortly before transitioning into an extratropical cyclone, a [[1938 Atlantic hurricane season#Tropical Storm Seven|weak tropical storm]] hits near [[Yankeetown, Florida|Yankeetown]] and causes minor damage.<ref name="oct38">{{cite web|author=Jean Gallenne|year=1938|title=Tropical Disturbances of October 1938|publisher=U.S. Weather Bureau|accessdate=2007-05-07|url=http://docs.lib.noaa.gov/rescue/mwr/066/mwr-066-10-0325.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> * June 16, 1939 – The [[1939 Atlantic hurricane season#Tropical Storm One|first storm]] of the season hits near [[Mobile, Alabama]], with its outer [[Rainband#Tropical cyclones|rainbands]] dropping heavy rainfall across Florida and killing one child in [[Wauchula, Florida|Wauchula]].<ref name="jun39">{{cite web|author=Jean Gallenne|year=1939|title=Tropical Disturbance of June 12–16, 1939|publisher=U.S. Weather Bureau|accessdate=2007-05-06|url=http://docs.lib.noaa.gov/rescue/mwr/067/mwr-067-06-0175.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> * August 11, 1939 – A [[1939 Atlantic hurricane season#Hurricane Two|minimal hurricane]] hits Fort Pierce and later on the panhandle near Apalachicola. The storm causes minor damage, limited to uprooted trees and power outages, and kills one after rough waves capsized a boat at Cedar Key.<ref name="aug39">{{cite web|author=I.R. Tannehille|year=1939|title=Tropical Disturbance of August 1939|publisher=U.S. Weather Bureau|accessdate=2007-05-06|url=http://docs.lib.noaa.gov/rescue/mwr/067/mwr-067-08-0296.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> * September 26, 1939 – 49 mph (79 km/h) wind gusts and no damage is reported in occurrence with a [[1939 Atlantic hurricane season#Tropical Storm Three|weak tropical storm]] hitting Louisiana.<ref name="sept39">{{cite web|author=Willis E. Hurd|year=1939|title=Tropical Disturbance of September 24–26, 1939 in the Gulf of Mexico|publisher=U.S. Weather Bureau|accessdate=2007-05-06|url=http://docs.lib.noaa.gov/rescue/mwr/067/mwr-067-09-0340.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref>
==1940–1949== * August 2, 1940 – Light winds are reported in association with a [[1940 Atlantic hurricane season#Hurricane Two|tropical storm]] moving across the northern portion of the state; no damage is reported.<ref name="aug40">{{cite web|author=Jean Gallenne|year=1940|title=Tropical Disturbances of August 1940|publisher=U.S. Weather Bureau|accessdate=2007-05-06|url=http://docs.lib.noaa.gov/rescue/mwr/068/mwr-068-08-0217.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> * October 6, 1941 – A [[1941 Florida hurricane|hurricane]] hits near Miami with gusts reaching 123 mph (199 km/h) and later moves ashore along the Florida Panhandle. Its accompanying 4.1 foot (1.25 m) storm surge causes coastal flooding in the southeast portion of the state. The hurricane drowns five people in [[Carrabelle, Florida|Carrabelle]], and damage across the state totals about $675,000 (1941 USD, $9.9 million 2008 USD).<ref name="oct41">{{cite web|author=H.C. Sumner|year=1941|title=Hurricane of October 3–12 and Tropical Disturbance of October 18–21, 1941|publisher=U.S. Weather Bureau|accessdate=2007-05-06|url=http://docs.lib.noaa.gov/rescue/mwr/069/mwr-069-10-0303.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> * October 20, 1941 – The [[1941 Atlantic hurricane season#Tropical Storm Six|final storm]] of the season moves ashore near Cedar Key after previously passing through the Florida Keys. It drops heavy rainfall which causes some flooding damage.<ref name="oct41"/> * September 10, 1944 – A [[1944 Atlantic hurricane season#Tropical Storm Six|tropical storm]] hits southeastern Louisiana, with the eastern portion of its circulation causing slight crop damage and gale force winds across the western Florida Panhandle.<ref name="1944mwr">{{cite web|author=H.C. Sumner|year=1944|title=Hurricanes and Tropical Disturbances of 1944|publisher=U.S. Weather Bureau|accessdate=2007-05-03|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/general/lib/lib1/nhclib/mwreviews/1944.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> * October 19, 1944 – The [[Pinar del Río Hurricane of 1944|final hurricane]] of the season strikes near [[Sarasota, Florida|Sarasota]] with winds of over 115 mph (185 km/h). The winds severely damage the citrus crop, which accounts for about 80% of the damage total of $63 million (1944 USD, $772 million 2008 USD) in the state. A total of 18 people are killed in the state.<ref name="1944mwr"/> * June 24, 1945 – An early season [[1945 Atlantic hurricane season#Hurricane One|hurricane]] moves inland between [[Brooksville, Florida|Brooksville]] and [[Dunnellon, Florida|Dunnellon]], and spawns one tornado near [[Melbourne, Florida|Melbourne]]. No lives are lost, which is credited due to the evacuation of thousands from the coast. Damage in the state is minor.<ref name="0645storm">{{cite web|author=Mary O. Souder|year=1945|title=Severe Local Storms, June 1945|publisher=Monthly Weather Review|accessdate=2007-05-03|url=http://docs.lib.noaa.gov/rescue/mwr/073/mwr-073-06-0109.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> * September 4, 1945 – A weak tropical storm brushes the western coastline before turning to the northwest, and causes minor damage to boats in Miami.<ref name="1945mwr">{{cite web|author=H.C. Sumner|year=1946|title=Hurricanes and Tropical Disturbances of 1945|publisher=U.S. Weather Bureau|accessdate=2007-05-03|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/general/lib/lib1/nhclib/mwreviews/1945.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> * September 15, 1945 – The [[1945 Southeast Florida hurricane|ninth storm]] of the season, a Category 4 hurricane, strikes [[Key Largo, Florida|Key Largo]] with wind gusts reaching 150 mph (240 km/h). The winds ignite a fire at three hangars at the [[Richmond West, Florida|Richmond]] [[Naval Air Station]], which destroys 25 blimps, 366 planes, and 150 automobiles. Across the state, the passage of the hurricane results in 1,632 destroyed houses, with an additional 5,372 damaged. Damage amounts to $54 million (1945 USD, $647 million 2008 USD), of which nearly half occurs at the Richmond Air Station. Four people are killed in the state, with an additional 43 injured.<ref name="1945mwr"/> * October 8, 1946 – Rapidly weakening from peak, the [[1946 Florida hurricane|fifth storm]] of the season hits the [[Tampa Bay area]] as a minimal hurricane, this makes this the last hurricane to directly hit the Tampa Bay area to date. The hurricane causes moderate crop damage in the western portion of the state, with its storm surge resulting in additional coastal damage. Monetary damage across the state totals about $5.2 million (1946 USD, $57.5 million 2008 USD).<ref name="1946mwr">{{cite web|author=H.C. Sumner|year=1946|title=North Atlantic Hurricanes and Tropical Disturbances of 1946|publisher=U.S. Weather Bureau|url=http://docs.lib.noaa.gov/rescue/mwr/074/mwr-074-12-0215.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> * November 1, 1946 – The [[1946 Atlantic hurricane season#Tropical Storm Six|last storm]] of the season moves ashore near [[Palm Beach, Florida|Palm Beach]] as a minimal tropical storm; inland, it drops heavy rainfall which causes millions of dollars in crop damage.<ref name="1946mwr"/> [[Image:September1947 Miami.jpg|right|thumb|250px|Surf from [[1947 Fort Lauderdale Hurricane]]]] * August 18, 1947 – Winds gusts reach 45 mph (75 km/h) along the Florida Keys in association with a developing [[1947 Atlantic hurricane season#Tropical Disturbance Three|tropical storm]].<ref name="1947mwr">{{cite web|author=H.C. Sumner|year=1947|title=North Atlantic Hurricanes and Tropical Disturbances of 1947|publisher=U.S. Weather Bureau|url=http://docs.lib.noaa.gov/rescue/mwr/075/mwr-075-12-0251.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> * September 8, 1947 – A weak [[1947 Atlantic hurricane season#Minor Tropical Disturbance Five|tropical storm]] moves ashore in Mississippi, with its outer rainbands producing winds of 51 mph at Pensacola.<ref name="1947mwr"/> * September 17, 1947 – The [[1947 Fort Lauderdale Hurricane]] strikes the southeastern portion of the state with wind gusts of at least 155 mph (250 km/h); sustained winds of over 100 mph (160 km/h) occur along 70 miles (120 km) of the eastern coastline. The hurricane produces heavy rainfall, which causes damaging flooding along crop fields. Heavy damage is also reported from Fort Myers to Sarasota, and statewide damage from the hurricane totals about $31 million (1947 USD, $300 million 2008 USD). The hurricane causes 11 direct fatalities in the state, and is indirectly responsible for six more.<ref name="1947mwr"/> * September 23, 1947 – The [[1947 Atlantic hurricane season#Tropical Disturbance Seven|seventh storm]] of the season hits near Yankeetown, dropping moderate rainfall which causes further flooding across the southern portion of the state.<ref name="1947mwr"/> Nine tornadoes are spawned by the storm, which collectively destroy three houses and damage dozens of houses.<ref name="0947storm">{{cite web|author=U.S. Weather Bureau|year=1947|title=Severe Storms for September 1947|publisher=Monthly Weather Review|accessdate=2007-05-02|url=http://docs.lib.noaa.gov/rescue/mwr/075/mwr-075-09-0183.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> * October 7, 1947 – A [[1947 Atlantic hurricane season#Tropical Disturbance Eight|tropical storm]] hits near the Florida/Georgia border, and after turning southwestward into the Gulf of Mexico loops to the northeast through the Florida Panhandle. The storm causes high tides and beach erosion along the eastern coastline.<ref name="upi1007">{{cite news|author=Staff Writer|publisher=United Press International|date=1947-10-07|title=Storm Sweeps Through Georgia|accessdate=2007-05-02|url=http://www.thehurricanearchive.com/Viewer.aspx?img=51692295&firstvisit=true&src=search&currentResult=4&currentPage=0|format=PDF|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160118121151/http://www.thehurricanearchive.com/Viewer.aspx?img=51692295&firstvisit=true&src=search&currentResult=4&currentPage=0|archivedate=2016-01-18|df=}}</ref> * October 12, 1947 – A [[1947 Atlantic hurricane season#Severe Hurricane Nine|hurricane]] moves across the southern portion of the state and drops up to 13 inches (330 mm) of rainfall; the rainfall causes further flooding damage which ends an unusually wet season in the state. Wind damage is minor.<ref name="1947mwr"/> * July 9, 1948 – The [[1948 Atlantic hurricane season#Tropical Storm Two|second storm]] of the season hits near [[Destin, Florida|Destin]]. Some low-lying areas are flooded from heavy rainfall, but damage is minor.<ref name="jul48">{{cite web|author=U.S. Weather Bureau|year=1948|title=Severe Storms for July 1948|publisher=Monthly Weather Review|accessdate=2007-05-01|url=http://docs.lib.noaa.gov/rescue/mwr/076/mwr-076-07-0143.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref><ref name="1948mwr">{{cite web|author=H.C. Sumner|year=1949|title=North Atlantic Hurricanes and Tropical Disturbances of 1948|publisher=U.S. Weather Bureau|accessdate=2007-05-01|url=http://docs.lib.noaa.gov/rescue/mwr/076/mwr-076-12-0277.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> * September 4, 1948 – A [[1948 Atlantic hurricane season#Hurricane Five|hurricane]] moves ashore along southern Louisiana, with its high tides extending eastward and reaching 3.4 feet at Pensacola. Damage is minor along the Florida Panhandle.<ref name="1948mwr"/> * September 21, 1948 – The Florida Keys are struck by a [[1948 Atlantic hurricane season#Hurricane Seven|hurricane]] which produces wind gusts of over 122 mph (197 km/h). It drops moderate to heavy rainfall across the southern portion of the state, peaking at 11 inches (280 mm) in Miami, and causes considerable flooding. Across the state, the hurricane severely damages 1,161 homes and destroys 39 others, with damage totaling $12 million (1948 USD, $107 million 2008 USD). Three people are killed, with another 45 hospitalized.<ref name="1948mwr"/> * October 5, 1948 – The [[1948 Atlantic hurricane season#Hurricane Eight|fifth hurricane]] of the season hits the Florida Keys and brushes the southern portion of the state with winds of over 100 mph (160 km/h). The storm spawns 3 tornadoes, one of which destroys 25 houses in [[Pompano Beach, Florida|Pompano Beach]]. 678 homes are destroyed or severely damaged, and damage across the state totals $5.5 million (1948 USD, $49 million 2008 USD). The hurricane injures 42, though no deaths are reported in the state.<ref name="1948mwr"/> * August 26, 1949 – A Category 4 [[1949 Atlantic hurricane season#Hurricane Two|hurricane]] strikes Jupiter with wind gusts of over 153 mph (247 km/h). The winds severely damage crops across its path, with the avocado and grapefruit crops sustaining heavy losses. Many houses along its path are damaged, as well, and monetary damage in the state totals $45 million (1949 USD, $408 million 2008 USD).<ref name="aug49">{{cite web|author=U.S. Weather Bureau|year=1949|title=Severe Storms for August 1949|publisher=Monthly Weather Review|accessdate=2007-05-01|url=http://docs.lib.noaa.gov/rescue/mwr/077/mwr-077-08-0244.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> Additionally, four people are killed in the state, though it is unknown if all are directly related to the hurricane.<ref name="mth829">{{cite web|author=Middletown Times Herald|date=1949-08-29|title=Storm Warnings Up Along Coast, Hurricane Fades|accessdate=2007-05-01|url=http://www.thehurricanearchive.com/Viewer.aspx?img=35319975&firstvisit=true&src=search&currentResult=1&currentPage=0|format=PDF|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160118121151/http://www.thehurricanearchive.com/Viewer.aspx?img=35319975&firstvisit=true&src=search&currentResult=1&currentPage=0|archivedate=2016-01-18|df=}}</ref>
==Monthly statistics== {{bar graph|float=center | title = Number of recorded storms affecting Florida | data_max = 45 | label_type = Month | data_type = Number of storms | label4 = April | data4 = | label5 = May | data5 = 2 | label6 = June | data6 = 10 | label7 = July | data7 = 9 | label8 = August | data8 = 18 | label9 = September | data9 = 40 | label10 = October | data10 = 23 | label11 = November | data11 = 5 | label12 = December | data12 = 1 }}
==Deadly storms== The following is a list of hurricanes with known deaths in the state.
<center> {| class="wikitable" align="center" |- bgcolor="#CCCCCC" ! Name ! Year ! Number of deaths |- | Okeechobee || 1928 || ~2,500 |- | Labor Day || 1935 || 409 |- | Miami || 1926 || 372 |- | [[1906 Atlantic hurricane season|Florida Keys]] || 1906 || 141 |- | Unnamed || 1906 || 32 |- | [[Sanibel Island Hurricane of 1944|Unnamed]] || 1944 || 18 |- | [[1909 Atlantic hurricane season|Unnamed]] || 1909 || 13 |- | [[1910 Atlantic hurricane season|Unnamed]] || 1910 || 11 |- | Fort Lauderdale || 1947 || 11 |- | [[1903 Atlantic hurricane season|Unnamed]] || 1903 || 9 |- | [[1904 Atlantic hurricane season|Unnamed]] || 1904 || 7 (offshore) |- | [[1917 Atlantic hurricane season|Unnamed]] || 1917 || 5 |- | Tampa Bay || 1921 || 5 |- | [[1935 Atlantic hurricane season|Yankee]] || 1935 || 5 |- | [[1941 Atlantic hurricane season|Unnamed]] || 1941 || 5 |- | [[1928 Atlantic hurricane season|Unnamed]] || 1928 || 4 |- | [[1945 Atlantic hurricane season|Unnamed]] || 1945 || 4 |- | [[1949 Atlantic hurricane season|Unnamed]] || 1949 || 4 |- | Miami || 1929 || 3 |- | [[1948 Atlantic hurricane season|Unnamed]] || 1948 || 3 |- | [[1933 Atlantic hurricane season|Unnamed]] || 1933 || 2 |- | [[1916 Atlantic hurricane season|Unnamed]] || 1916 || 1 |- | [[1926 Atlantic hurricane season|Unnamed]] || 1926 || 1 |- | [[1939 Atlantic hurricane season|Unnamed]] || 1939 || 1 |- | [[1936 Atlantic hurricane season|Unnamed]] || 1936 || 0 (4 indirect) |- | Unnamed || 1936 || 0 (3 indirect) |} </center>

page.title: List of Sites of Special Scientific Interest in Staffordshire

revision.text:
This is a list of the [[Sites of Special Scientific Interest]] (SSSIs) in [[Staffordshire, England]]. For other counties, see [[List of SSSIs by Area of Search]].
* Allimore Green Common * [[Alvecote Pools]] * [[Aqualate Mere]] * [[Baswich Meadows]] * [[Bath Pasture]] * [[Belvide Reservoir]] * [[Betley Mere]] * [[Biddulph's Pool And No Man's Bank]] * [[Big Hyde Rough]] * [[Black Firs & Cranberry Bog]] * [[Blithfield Reservoir]] * [[Braken Hurst]] * [[Brownend Quarry]] * [[Burnt Wood]] * [[Caldon Dales]] * [[Caldon Low]] * [[Cannock Chase]] * [[Cannock Extension Canal]] * [[Cauldon Railway Cutting]] * [[Chartley Moss]] * [[Chasewater Heaths]] * [[Checkhill Bogs]] * [[Churnet Valley]] * [[Colshaw Pastures]] * [[Combes Valley]] * [[Cop Mere]] * [[Dimmings Dale & The Ranger]] * [[Doley Common]] * [[Dove Valley And Biggin Dale]] * [[Doxey And Tillington Marshes]] * [[Ecton Mines|Ecton Copper Mines]] * [[Ford Green Brook|Ford Green Reedbed]] * [[Forest Banks]] * [[Four Ashes Pit]] * [[Froghall Meadow And Pastures]] * [[ Gentleshaw Common]] * [[Goat Lodge]] * [[Gospel End Road Cutting]] * [[Hamps And Manifold Valleys]] * [[Highgate Common]] * [[Hulme Quarry]] * [[King's And Hargreaves Woods]] * [[Kinver Edge]] * [[Leek Moors]] * [[Loynton Moss]] * [[Maer Pool]] * [[Metallic Tileries, Parkhouse]] * [[Milford Quarry]] * [[Moss Carr]] * [[Mottey Meadows]] * [[Old River Dove, Marston On Dove]] * [[Pasturefields Salt Marsh]] * [[Rawbones Meadow]] * [[River Mease]] * [[Rue Hill]] * [[Saltersford Lane Meadows]] * [[Stafford Brook]] * [[Stanton Pastures & Cuckoocliff Valley]] * [[Stowe Pool]] and [[Walk Mill Clay Pit]] * [[Swineholes Wood And Blackheath]] * [[The Wilderness & Vermin Valley]] * [[Thorncliffe Moor]] * [[Wetley Moor]] * [[Whiston Eaves]] * [[Wollaston Ridge Quarry]]

The following is a '''list of [[ecoregion]]s in [[Cambodia]]'''.<ref>[http://wwf.panda.org/about_our_earth/ecoregions/ecoregion_list/ecoregions_country/ecoregions_country_c.cfm WWF; Ecoregions by country - C]</ref><ref>[http://www.eoearth.org/topics/view/51cbfc79f702fc2ba8129ee0/ Encyclopedia of earth - Ecoregions]</ref> ==Tropical and subtropical moist broadleaf forests== [[Tropical and subtropical moist broadleaf forests]]: *[[Annamite Range moist forests]] ([[Cambodia]], [[Laos]], [[Vietnam]]) *[[Cardamom Mountains moist forests]] ([[Cambodia]], [[Thailand]]) ==Tropical and subtropical dry broadleaf forests== [[Tropical and subtropical dry broadleaf forests]] *[[Central Indochina dry forests]] ([[Burma]], [[Laos]], [[Cambodia]], [[Thailand]], [[Vietnam]])
==Freshwater ecoregions== [[Freshwater ecoregions]]: * [[Mekong]] ([[Burma]], [[Laos]], [[Cambodia]], [[Thailand]], [[Vietnam]])
==References== {{Reflist}} * Wikramanayake, Eric; Eric Dinerstein; Colby J. Loucks; et al. (2002). ''Terrestrial Ecoregions of the Indo-Pacific: a Conservation Assessment.'' Washington, DC: Island Press
{{Cambodia topics}} {{Asia in topic|List of ecoregions in}} {{Biomes}}
[[Category:Ecoregions of Asia|*]] [[Category:Environment of Cambodia|Ecoregions]] [[Category:Flora of Cambodia|*]] [[Category:Lists of ecoregions by country|Cambodia]] [[Category:Cambodia geography-related lists|Cambodia]] [[Category:Natural history of Cambodia]] [[Category:Indomalaya ecoregions]]

This is a list of '''environmental [[periodicals]]''', in print and online, focused on various aspects of the [[biophysical environment]], the [[built environment]], humans' relations to those environments, and other environment topics. This list presently includes literary magazines, general-interest magazines, newsletters, and others.
:''(For [[peer-reviewed]] [[academic journal]]s, see the [[List of environmental journals]]. For online or hybrid periodicals, see also [[List of environmental websites]].)''
== Literary magazines == *''[[The Bear Deluxe]]'' — based out of [[Portland, Oregon]], United States *''[[Camas (magazine)|Camas: The Nature of the West]]'' — run by graduate students at the [[University of Montana]] *''[[Whole Terrain|Whole Terrain: Journal of Reflective Environmental Practice]]'' — published approximately once a year by [[Antioch University New England]]
== Newsletters and newspapers == *''[[ClimateWire]]'' — daily news service by [[Environment & Energy Publishing]], USA *''[[Down to Earth (magazine)|Down to Earth]]'' — science and environment magazine fortnightly published in India by the [[Centre for Science and Environment]] *''[[The ENDS Report]]'' — based in the UK and published by Environmental Data Services Ltd. *''[[EU Forest Watch]]'' — monthly forest issues newsletter focusing on the European Union, published by [[FERN]] *''[[The Green Economist]]'' — published by the [[Green Economics Institute]], [[Reading, Berkshire|Reading]], UK *''[[Greenwire]]'' — daily electronic newsletter by [[Environment & Energy Publishing]], USA *''[[Hawaii Island Journal]]'' — published on the Big Island of Hawaii *''[[Manchester Climate Fortnightly]]'' — published (online and on recycled paper) in Manchester, England
== Popular magazines == *''[[A\J: Alternatives Journal]]'' — official publication of the Environmental Studies Association of Canada; based in Waterloo, Ontario *''[[Checkerspot (magazine)|Checkerspot]]'' — published by the Canadian Wildlife Federation *''[[E–The Environmental Magazine]]'' — published by the Earth Action Network, based in [[Escondido, California]] *''[[Earth First! (magazine)|Earth First! Journal]]'' — published by [[Earth First!]] *''[[Ecology and Law]]'' — quarterly environmental advocacy and news magazine of the [[Bellona - St. Petersburg|Bellona Foundation]], [[Saint Petersburg]], Russia *''[[ECOS (CSIRO magazine)|ECOS]]'' (Australia) — Australian environmental magazine published by [[CSIRO]] *''[[ECOS (BANC magazine)|ECOS]]'' (UK) — quarterly publication of the [[British Association of Nature Conservationists]] *''[[Environment (magazine)|Environment]]'' magazine — "Science and Policy for Sustainable Development," published in Philadelphia by [[Taylor & Francis]] *''[[The Environmentalist]]'' — public interest, eco-investigative online magazine *''[[Environment Coastal & Offshore (ECO)]]'' — multi-media global publication focused on coastal and ocean environmental issues. Founded in 2012. Published by TSC Publishing in Stuart, Florida. *''[[G Magazine (Australia)|G: The Green Lifestyle Magazine]]'' — published in Sydney, Australia *''[[Gobar Times]]'' — monthly environmental education magazine for young adults, published in India by the [[Centre for Science and Environment]] *''[[Green Car Journal]]'' *''[[The Green Guide]]'' — produced by the [[National Geographic Society]] *''[[Grist (magazine)|Grist]]'' (online magazine) — headquartered in Seattle, Washington *''[[High Country News]]'' — magazine, website, and op-ed column addressing public lands, water, natural resources, grazing, wilderness, wildlife, logging, growth and other issues in the American West *''[[Home Power (magazine)|Home Power]]'' — based in Ashland, Oregon *''[[InsideClimate News]]'' (online magazine) — based in Brooklyn, New York *''[[Mongabay]]'' (online magazine) — based in Menlo Park, California *''[[Mother Earth News]]'' — based in Topeka, Kansas *''[[Natural History (magazine)|Natural History]]'' — published by the [[American Museum of Natural History]], aiming to promote public understanding and appreciation of nature and science *''[[Natural Home & Garden]]'' — American bimonthly magazine about sustainable homes and lifestyle *''[[Natural Life (magazine)|Natural Life]]'' — based in Canada and owned by Life Media *''[[Orion (magazine)|Orion]]'' — published by the Orion Society and based in [[Great Barrington, Massachusetts]] *''[[ReNew]]'' — Australian magazine first published by the Alternative Energy Co-operative in 1980 *''[[Resurgence & Ecologist]]'' — British bi-monthly green magazine *''[[Sanctuary Asia]]'' — India's first and one of its leading environmental news magazines *''[[Sierra Magazine]]'' — the national magazine of the [[Sierra Club]]
== Specialized periodicals == *''[[Chinadialogue]]'' — online magazine based in London, Beijing and San Francisco *''[[Corporate Knights]]'' — quarterly Canadian magazine focusing on corporate social and environmental responsibility *''[[Earth Negotiations Bulletin]]'' — internet publication covering international environmental negotiations, workshops and conferences, published by the Reporting Services arm of the International Institute for Sustainable Development *''[[The ENDS Report]]'' — published monthly by Environmental Data Services Ltd, now part of the [[Haymarket Group]] *''[[The Green Economist]]'' — news journal, published by the [[Green Economics Institute]] *''[[Journal of Contemporary Water Research & Education]]'' — published by the Universities Council on Water Resources *''[[Landscope]]'' — quarterly journal of the [[Department of Environment and Conservation (Western Australia)|Western Australia Department of Environment and Conservation]] *''[[New York State Conservationist]]'' — published by the [[New York State Department of Environmental Conservation]] *''[[Noise & Health]]'' — published by [[Medknow Publications]] on behalf of the Noise Research Network *''[[Organic Matters]]'' — published by the [[Irish Organic Farmers and Growers Association]]
== Defunct periodicals == *''[[The Ecologist]]'' — British environmental magazine, 1970-2009; now merged with ''Resurgence'' *''[[Energy Matters]]'' — discontinued; published by students at the University of Cambridge between November 1980 and June 1984 *''[[European Nuclear Disarmament Journal]]'' — discontinued; bi-monthly magazine of the [[European Nuclear Disarmament]] group in the United Kingdom * ''[[Wild Earth]]'' — discontinued; published in the United States *''[[Worldchanging]]'' — published in San Francisco, then Seattle, Washington, from 2003-2010
==See also== *[[List of environmental journals]] — for peer-reviewed, scholarly periodicals *[[List of environmental websites]] *[[Lists of environmental publications]]
== External links == *[http://www.deb.uminho.pt/fontes/enviroinfo/publications/ EnviroInfo: list of environmental periodicals]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Environmental periodicals}} [[Category:Lists of environmental topics|Periodicals]] [[Category:Lists of magazines]] [[Category:Environmental magazines| ]] [[Category:Literary magazines|*]]

==Peaks above 6,000 metres == [[File:Huascaran norte.JPG|thumb|right|[[Huascarán]] Sur]] [[File:Yerupaja Grande.jpg|thumb|right|[[Yerupajá]]]] [[File:Coropuna Volcano.jpg|thumb|right|[[Coropuna]]]] [[File:Nevado Huantsan.jpg|thumb|right|[[Huantsan]]]] [[File:Ausangate.jpg|thumb|right|[[Ausangate]]]] This is a list of the thirty-seven 6000 metre [[mountain|peaks]] in [[Peru]] as defined by a regain height, or [[Topographic prominence|prominence]], above a col of 300m or more. This list is taken from the full set of Peruvian IGM mapsPeruvian Instituto Geografico Militar 1:100, 000 map series published in Lima, various dates from 1950's to present, Sheets 18-h, 19-h, 19-i, 20-i, 21-j, 27-q, 28-t, 28-u, 30-y, 31-q, 32-q, 32-s and 33-s cover the 6000m peaks of Peru. alongside various climbing and mountaineering records.J. Neate (1994). Mountaineering in the Andes, p187. RGS 1994, {{ISBN|0-907649-64-5}}J. Biggar(2005). The Andes - A Guide for Climbers, p279. pub. Andes, {{ISBN|0-9536087-2-7}} Heights are taken from the Peruvian IGM 1:100,000 series maps with the OEAV survey maps Alpenverienskarte sheets 0/3a and 0/3b published 1999 and 2005. {{ISBN|3-928777-57-2}} and {{ISBN|3-937530-05-3}} of the Cordillera Blanca (north and south) used where the IGM maps do not give spot heights. SRTM data has been used in a few places to confirm these heights, but due to the steep terrain is often unusableFerranti 2005, "Peru ultra-Prominences", op. cit. {| class="wikitable sortable" |- !VALIGN=TOP| [[Mountain]] !VALIGN=TOP| [[Summit (topography)|Elevation]]
(metres) !VALIGN=TOP| [[Administrative divisions of Peru|Region]] !VALIGN=TOP| [[Mountain range]] |- | [[Huascarán]] S | 6,768 | [[Ancash Region|Ancash]] | [[Cordillera Blanca]] |- | [[Huascarán]] N | 6,655 | [[Ancash Region|Ancash]] | [[Cordillera Blanca]] |- | [[Yerupajá]] | 6,617 | [[Ancash Region|Ancash]] | [[Cordillera Huayhuash]] |- | [[Yerupaja Chico]] | 6,121 | [[Ancash Region|Ancash]] | [[Cordillera Huayhuash]] |- | [[Coropuna]] | 6,425 | [[Arequipa Region|Arequipa]] | [[Cordillera Occidental, Peru|Cordillera Occidental]] |- | Coropuna Casulla | 6,377 | [[Arequipa Region|Arequipa]] | [[Cordillera Occidental, Peru|Cordillera Occidental]] |- | Coropuna E | 6,305 | [[Arequipa Region|Arequipa]] | [[Cordillera Occidental, Peru|Cordillera Occidental]] |- | [[Huandoy]] | 6,395 | [[Ancash Region|Ancash]] | [[Cordillera Blanca]] |- | Huandoy S | 6,160 | [[Ancash Region|Ancash]] | [[Cordillera Blanca]] |- | [[Ausangate]] | 6,372 | [[Cusco Region|Cusco]] | [[Cordillera Vilcanota]] |- | [[Huantsan]] (Tunshu) | 6,369 | [[Ancash Region|Ancash]] | [[Cordillera Blanca]] |- | [[Chopicalqui]] | 6,345 | [[Ancash Region|Ancash]] | [[Cordillera Blanca]] |- | [[Siula Grande]] | 6,344 | [[Lima Region|Lima]]-[[Huánuco Region|Huánuco]] | [[Cordillera Huayhuash]] |- | [[Chinchey]] (Rurichinchay) | 6,309 | [[Ancash Region|Ancash]] | [[Cordillera Blanca]] |- | [[Ampato]] | 6,288 | [[Arequipa Region|Arequipa]] | [[Cordillera Occidental, Peru|Cordillera Occidental]] |- | [[Palcaraju]] | 6,274 | [[Ancash Region|Ancash]] | [[Cordillera Blanca]] |- | [[Salcantay]] | 6,271 | [[Cusco Region|Cusco]] | [[Vilcabamba mountain range|Cordillera Vilcabamba]] |- | [[Santa Cruz (mountain)|Santa Cruz]] | 6,241 | [[Ancash Region|Ancash]] | [[Cordillera Blanca]] |- | [[Nevado Copa|Copa]] | 6,188 | [[Ancash Region|Ancash]] | [[Cordillera Blanca]] |- | [[Ranrapalca]] | 6,162 | [[Ancash Region|Ancash]] | [[Cordillera Blanca]] |- | [[Pucaranra]] | 6,156 | [[Ancash Region|Ancash]] | [[Cordillera Blanca]] |- | [[Hualcán]] (Rahupakinan) | 6,122 | [[Ancash Region|Ancash]] | [[Cordillera Blanca]] |- | [[Callangate]] (a.k.a. Qullpa Ananta, Cayangate or Chimboya) | 6,110 | [[Cusco Region|Cusco]] | [[Cordillera Vilcanota]] |- | [[Alcamarinayoc]] (a.k.a. Qullqi Cruz) | 6,102 | [[Cusco Region|Cusco]] | [[Cordillera Vilcanota]] |- | [[Chacraraju]] | 6,108 | [[Ancash Region|Ancash]] | [[Cordillera Blanca]] |- | [[Jirishanca]] | 6,094 | [[Ancash Region|Ancash]]-[[Huánuco Region|Huánuco]] | [[Cordillera Huayhuash]] |- | [[Chachani]] | 6,057 | [[Arequipa Region|Arequipa]] | [[Cordillera Occidental, Peru|Cordillera Occidental]] |- | [[Chumpe]] (a.k.a. Hatunrit'i, Ñañaluma, Wisk'achani, Yanaluma) | 6,106 | [[Cusco Region|Cusco]] | [[Cordillera Vilcanota]] |- | [[Hatunuma]] (Pico Tres) | 6,093 | [[Cusco Region|Cusco]] | [[Cordillera Vilcanota]] |- | [[Solimana (volcano)|Solimana]] | 6,093 | [[Arequipa Region|Arequipa]] | [[Cordillera Occidental, Peru|Cordillera Occidental]] |- | [[Hualca Hualca]] | 6,025 | [[Arequipa Region|Arequipa]] | [[Cordillera Occidental, Peru|Cordillera Occidental]] |- | [[Yayamari]] (Montura) | 6,049 | [[Cusco Region|Cusco]] | [[Cordillera Vilcanota]] |- | [[Chaupi Orco (mountain)|Chaupi Orco]] | 6,044 | [[Puno Region|Puno]]- [[Bolivia]] | [[Cordillera Apolobamba]] |- | [[Pucajirca]] | 6,046 | [[Ancash Region|Ancash]] | [[Cordillera Blanca]] |- | [[Quitaraju]] | 6,036 | [[Ancash Region|Ancash]] | [[Cordillera Blanca]] |- | [[Tocllaraju]] | 6,034 | [[Ancash Region|Ancash]] | [[Cordillera Blanca]] |- | [[Caraz (mountain)|Caraz]] | 6,025 | [[Ancash Region|Ancash]] | [[Cordillera Blanca]] |} ==Peaks less than 6000m== Many peaks in Peru frequently quoted as being over 6000m are under this height according to the most recent surveys published by the Peruvian IGM. These peaks include:- [[Pumasillo]] 5,991m, Lasunayoc 5,936m, [[Yanarahu (Asunción-Carhuaz-Yungay)|Yanarahu]] 5,954m, [[Artesonraju]] 5,999m, [[Sabancaya]] 5,976m, [[Palumani]] 5,723m, Sara Sara 5,505m, Helancoma 5,367m. ==Sub-peaks with less than 300m re-ascent== Other 6,000 m peaks which are often defined as individual peaks but which have less than 300 m of re-ascent or [[prominence]], include:- Huandoy W 6,342 m (prominence between 200-250m), Sarapu 6,127 (prominence between 180-230m), Callangate North 6,000 m (less than 295m prominence). Qaras E (6025m) and [[Rasac]] (6,017 m) may or may not have 300m prominence. There is insufficient data on the relevant Peruvian IGM maps. == Mountain ranges == Peru is home to a number of mountain ranges, including the following: {{columns-list|colwidth=30em| * [[Chila mountain range]] * [[Chonta mountain range]] * [[Cordillera del Cóndor]] * [[Cordillera Apolobamba]] * [[Cordillera Blanca]] * [[Cordillera Carabaya]] * [[Cordillera Central (Peru)]] * [[Cordillera de Rentema]] * [[Cordillera Huayhuash]] * [[Cordillera Negra]] * [[Cordillera Occidental (Peru)]] * [[Cordillera Oriental (Peru)]] * [[Cordillera Vilcanota]] * [[Huaguruncho mountain range]] * [[Huallanca mountain range]] * [[Huanzo mountain range]] * [[Huaytapallana mountain range]] * [[La Raya mountain range]] * [[Pariacaca mountain range]] * [[Puwaq Hanka mountain range]] * [[Raura mountain range]] * [[Serra do Divisor]] * [[Urubamba mountain range]] * [[Vilcabamba mountain range]] }} ==See also== * [[Geography of Peru]] ==References== ; Sources consulted * {{Cite book | author = [[Instituto Nacional de Estadística e Informática|INEI]], Perú | year = 2005 | title = Perú: Compendio Estadístico 2005 | location = [[Lima]] | publisher = [[Instituto Nacional de Estadística e Informática]] | language = Spanish | page = 22 | id = }} ; Endnotes {{Reflist}} ==External links== The lists can be contradictory but are all useful. They use different criteria of [[prominence]] or re-ascent for defining major peaks and sub-peaks. * [http://www.andes.org.uk/andes-information-files/6000m-peaks.asp "The 6000m peaks of the Andes"] - a comprehensive, up-to-date and well researched list. * {{cite peakbagger |lid=2201 |name="Andes 6000-meter Peaks"}} at Peak Bagger.com – a hypertext list {{-}} {{South America topic|state=uncollapsed|List of mountains in}} {{Peru lists}} [[Category:Mountains of Peru|*]] [[Category:Lists of mountains by country|Peru]] [[Category:Lists of landforms of Peru|Mountains]]

revision.text:
{{unreferenced|date=August 2015}} {{Use British English|date=January 2011}}{{Use dmy dates|date=January 2011}} [[File:Giant Panda 2004-03-2.jpg|199px|thumb|right|The [[giant panda]] is an [[endangered species]]]] [[File:Monachoides vicinus dart lateral.jpg|thumb|right|240px|The use of [[love dart]]s by the land snail ''[[Monachoides vicinus]]'' is a form of [[sexual selection]]]] [[File:Silk worm adult01.JPG|199px|thumb|right|Adult [[silk worm]]]] [[Animal]]s are [[multicellular]] [[eukaryotic]] organisms that form the [[Kingdom (biology)|biological kingdom]] '''Animalia'''. With few exceptions, animals [[Heterotroph|consume organic material]], [[Cellular_respiration#Aerobic_respiration|breathe oxygen]], are [[Motility|able to move]], [[Sexual reproduction|reproduce sexually]], and grow from a hollow sphere of cells, the [[blastula]], during [[Embryogenesis|embryonic development]]. Over 1.5 million [[Extant taxon|living]] animal species have been [[Species description|described]]—of which around 1 million are [[Insecta|insects]]—but it has been estimated there are over 7 million in total. Animals range in size from 8.5 millionths of a metre to {{convert|33.6|m|ft}} long and have [[Ecology|complex interactions]] with each other and their environments, forming intricate [[food web]]s. The study of animals is called [[zoology]].
Animals may be listed or indexed by many criteria, including [[taxonomy (biology)|taxonomy]], status as [[endangered species]], their geographical location, and their portrayal and/or naming in human culture.
== By common name == * [[List of animal names]] (male, female, young, and group) * [[List of English animal nouns]]
== By aspect == * [[List of common household pests]] * [[List of animals by number of neurons]] === By domestication === {{main|domestication}} [[File:Water Buffalo, Phayao Lake.jpg|240px|thumb|right|Water buffalo]] *[[List of domesticated animals]]
=== By eating behaviour === *[[List of herbivorous animals]] *[[List of omnivores]]
=== By endangered status === {{main|Endangered species}} [[File:Andean cat 1 Jim Sanderson.jpg|thumb|The [[Andean mountain cat]] is an [[endangered species]].]] *[[IUCN Red List endangered species (Animalia)]] **[[United States Fish and Wildlife Service list of endangered species]]
